revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Lotika Sarkar | image = Lotika Sarkar.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1923|01|04}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2013|02|23|1923|01|04}} | death_place = New Delhi, India | nationality = Indian |alma_mater= [[Cambridge University]] |organization= [[Delhi University]]
[[Indian Law Institute]] | other_names = | occupation = feminist, educator and lawyer | known_for = }} '''Lotika Sarkar''' (4 January 1923 – 23 February 2013) was a noted Indian feminist, social worker, educator and lawyer, who was a pioneer in the field of [[women's studies]] and [[women's rights]] in India. She was a founding member of Centre for Women's Development Studies (CWDS), Delhi, established in 1980, and also Indian Association for Women Studies, established in 1982. Starting in 1951, she taught law at [[Faculty of Law, University of Delhi]] till 1983, and also remained the head of the Law Faculty, thereafter she taught at [[Indian Law Institute]]. She was the first Indian woman to graduate from [[Cambridge University]], and later in 1951 she also became the first woman to receive a PhD degree in law from the university.{{cite news |title=Few saw her in last two years|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-01-14/delhi/28027201_1_ips-officer-latika-sarkar-dhaundiyals |newspaper=The Times of India |date=14 January 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2013}} ==Early life and education== Born in 1923, she was raise in an aristocratic family in [[West Bengal]], where her father Sir Dhiren Mitra was leading lawyer of India.{{cite web |title=In Remembrance: Professor Lotika Sarkar (1923–2013)|url=http://barandbench.com/content/remembrance-professor-lotika-sarkar-1923-2013 |date=8 April 2013 |publisher=Bar and Bench |accessdate=5 June 2013}} Sarkar studied law at [[Newnham College, Cambridge]] and became the first Indian woman to study and also then graduate from the university.{{cite web|title=In memoriam: Lotika Sarkar 1923 – 2013|url=http://feministsindia.com/in-memoriam-lotika-sarkar-1927-2013/|publisher=feministsindia.com|accessdate=4 June 2013|date=2013-02-25}}{{cite book|author=Malini Chib|title=One Little Finger|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mtiGAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA7|date=11 January 2011|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-81-321-0671-5|page=7}} Later she wrote a PhD in Law, also at Cambridge University, awarded in 1951.{{cite news |title=Lawyer Here From India |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=s6ZVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hLoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7087,3745612&dq=lotika+sarkar&hl=en |publisher=[[The Age]], Australia|date= 26 July 1961 |accessdate=4 June 2013}} Thereafter in 1960, she studied [[international law]] at the [[Harvard University]], where she was one of four Indian students, returning to India in 1961. ==Career== In 1953, when Sarkar started teaching at the Law Faculty, University of Delhi, she was the first female lecturer in the faculty. Law was still a new field for women, initially there were only 10 girls in the course, a number which grew to 80–100 by the 1960s . She taught here till 1983, teaching eminent jurist and lawyers, and finally became the Head of the Law Faculty, and also the [[university don]].{{cite news |title=Lotika's friends meet Prez to seek justice |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-03-27/delhi/28020801_1_lotika-sarkar-nirmal-dhoundial-bihar-ips-officer |newspaper=The Times of India |date=27 March 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2013}} In 1971, she became a member of the Committee on the Status of Women in India (CSWI),[[#Ag|Agrawal, p. 61]] where along with her colleague, [[Vina Mazumdar]], who joined in 1973 as Member-Secretary,[[#Ag|Agrawal, p. 62]] there went on to publish the seminal, ''Towards Equality: The Report of the Committee on the Status of Women in India'' (1974–75){{cite web |title=Remembering Lotika Sarkar (1923–2013)|author=Indu Agnihotri|url=http://www.epw.in/commentary/remembering-lotika-sarkar-1923-2013.html |date=Vol – XLVIII No. 20, 18 May 2013 |publisher=[[Economic and Political Weekly]] |accessdate=3 June 2013}}{{cite news |title=Rolling stone who anchored the women's movement |author=Urvashi Butalia|authorlink=Urvashi Butalia|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/op-ed/rolling-stone-who-anchored-the-womens-movement/article4766709.ece |work=The Hindu |date=31 May 2013 |accessdate=3 June 2013}} In 1979, the [[Supreme Court of India]] reversed the judgment of [[Bombay High Court]] in the [[Mathura rape case]], in which two policemen were sentenced for raping of sixteen-year-old girl within a police station. The acquittal, went largely unnoticed until September 1979, when professors [[Upendra Baxi]], Raghunath Kelkar and Sarkar of [[Delhi University]] and Vasudha Dhagamwar of Pune, wrote an [[open letter]] to the Supreme Court, protesting the concept of consent in the judgment. "Consent involves submission, but the converse is not necessarily true...From the facts of case, all that is established is submission, and not consent...Is the taboo against pre-marital sex so strong as to provide a license to Indian police to rape young girls."[[#Kh|Khullar, p. 132]] Later in January 1980 she formed the first feminist group against rape, "Forum Against Rape", widespread protests followed and eventually [[Indian Penal Code]] was amended.{{cite web |title=The Mind And Heart of Lotika Sarkar, Legal Radical, Friend, Feminist |url=http://news.in.msn.com/her_courage/the-mind-and-heart-of-lotika-sarkar-legal-radical-friend-feminist |date=7 March 2013 |publisher=MSN News India |accessdate=5 June 2013}}{{cite news |last=Indira |first=Jaising |authorlink=Indira Jaising |title=Slamming the doors of justice on women |work=The Indian Express |date=20 January 1999 |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/Storyold/74290/ |accessdate=6 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/687aNhWS7?url=http://www.indianexpress.com/Storyold/74290/ |archivedate=2 June 2012 |df= }} In 1980, she became a founder member of Centre for Women's Development Studies (CWDS), Delhi, founded by Vina Mazumdar, and which went on to become an influential institution, impacting the course of [[women's studies]] in India.{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-03-08/india/28147826_1_first-report-middle-class-women-equality|title=Educated middle class women are selfish |date=8 March 2010|newspaper=The Times of India|first1=Rema|last1=Nagarajan}} Through the 1980s and 90s, she taught criminal law at the [[Indian Law Institute]] in Delhi. She was also a founding member of Indian Association for Women's Studies, established in 1982.{{cite web |title=Founding Members |url=http://www.iaws.org/ |publisher=Indian Association for Women's Studies |accessdate=5 June 2013}} ==Personal life== She met Chanchal Sarkar in 1951, while he too was studying at Cambridge, they married in 1957. Chanchal Sarkar went on to become an eminent journalist, assistant editor of ''[[The Statesman (India)|The Statesman]]'' and founding director of the Press Institute of India in 1963; he died on 10 October 2005 in Delhi.{{cite news |title=Chanchal Sarkar dead |url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/10/11/stories/2005101110301300.htm|work=The Hindu |date=11 October 2005 |accessdate=3 June 2013}}{{cite news |title=OBITUARY: Chanchal Sarkar (1926–2005) |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1051017/asp/opinion/story_5358748.asp |newspaper= The Telegraph|location=Kolkota |date= 17 October 2005|accessdate=5 June 2013}} The couple had no children.{{cite news |title=Latika hasn't run out of options|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-01-15/delhi/28006047_1_property-option-latika-sarkar |newspaper=The Times of India |date=15 January 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2013}} She continued to live thereafter at their [[Hauz Khas]], Delhi residence, which she was disposed of January 2009 by the tenants, which led to a media furore{{cite news |title=Owner's pride now friend, help's envy: catfight over house in Hauz Khas|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/owner-s-pride-now-friend-help-s-envy-catfight-over-house-in-hauz-khas/410404/0 |work=The Indian Express |date=14 January 2009 |accessdate=3 June 2013}} Several leading intellectuals, jurists, academics, journalists, activists and over a dozen national groups and institutions came forward in her support demanding speedy justice,{{cite news |title=150 notables demand justice for Lotika Sarkar|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-03-17/delhi/28016838_1_lotika-sarkar-nirmal-dhoundial-hauz-khas-enclave |newspaper=The Times of India |date=17 March 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2013}}{{cite news |title=Demand to transfer Lotika's property back to her|url=http://www.hindu.com/2009/03/17/stories/2009031754030400.htm|quote=a pioneer in the field of women's studies and human rights,.. |work= The Hindu|date=17 March 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2013}} some even met the President, before the house was restored to her by the courts in November 2009.{{cite news |title=Lotika Sarkar gets her house back after all |url=http://www.hindu.com/2009/11/27/stories/2009112757920100.htm |work=The Hindu |date=27 November 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2013}} She died in New Delhi on 23 February 2013, at the age of 90.{{cite news |title=Latika Sarkar, former head of DU law faculty, no more|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-02-24/delhi/37269789_1_legal-education-social-worker-head-of-du-law |newspaper=The Times of India |date=24 February 2013 |accessdate=3 June 2013}} ==Bibliography== * ''New Perspectives for Third World Women'' (The E. V. Mathew memorial lectures), with [[Brigalia Bam|Brigalia H. Bam]]. Christian Institute for the Study of Religion and Society, 1979. * ''National Policies and Legal Reform: Impact on Women'', Indian Council of Social Science Research, Programme of Women's Studies, 1980. * ''Constitutional Guarantees: The Unequal Sex'' Centre for Women's Development Studies, 1986. * ''National Specialised Agencies and Women's Equality: Law Commission of India''. Centre for Women's Development Studies, 1988. * ''Legislative Measures and Policy Directions for Improving the Lot of Farm Women'', with [[Vina Mazumdar]], Kumud Sarma. Indian Council of Agricultural Research. * ''Handbook on Women and Law, Vol. 1''. Legal Literacy Project, Department of Adult Continuing Education and Extension, University of Delhi, 1990. * ''Women's Movement and the Legal Process'', Centre for Women's Development Studies, 1995. * ''Engendering Law: Essays in Honour of Lotika Sarkar'', ed. Amita Dhanda, Archana Parashar. Eastern Book Company, 2005. {{ISBN|8170129540}}. == References == {{Reflist|2}} * {{cite book |title=Women's Education in India: 1986–1987 |author=Surendra P. Agrawal |author2=J. C. Aggarwal |publisher=Concept Publishing Company |year=1992|isbn=978-8170223184 |page= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bJD4EM2kvt0C&pg=PA61 |ref=Ag }} * {{cite book |title=Writing the Women's Movement: A Reader |author=Mala Khullar |author2=Ihwa Yŏja Taehakkyo |publisher=Zubaan|year=2005|isbn=978-8186706992 |page= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Efv3V7Y9WzsC&pg=PA132 |ref=Kh }} ==External links== * [http://www.authorstream.com/Presentation/eighteen-1751341-memorial-meeting-prof-latika-sarkar-13-2013/ Memorial Meeting, Prof. Lotika Sarkar] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sarkar, Lotika}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Indian feminists]] [[Category:Indian women academics]] [[Category:Indian legal scholars]] [[Category:Bengali people]] [[Category:Indian women's rights activists]] [[Category:Alumni of Newnham College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Harvard Law School alumni]] [[Category:University of Delhi faculty]] [[Category:Women educators from Delhi]] [[Category:Educators from Delhi]] [[Category:Women's studies academics]] [[Category:20th-century Indian lawyers]] [[Category:Legal educators]] [[Category:Indian legal writers]] [[Category:20th-century Indian women writers]] [[Category:20th-century Indian non-fiction writers]] [[Category:20th-century Indian educational theorists]] [[Category:20th-century Indian women scientists]] [[Category:20th-century Indian social scientists]] [[Category:Indian women activists]] [[Category:Indian women social workers]] [[Category:Indian women social scientists]] [[Category:Women scientists from West Bengal]] [[Category:Activists from West Bengal]] [[Category:Indian women scholars]] [[Category:Scholars from West Bengal]] [[Category:Indian academic administrators]] [[Category:Women academic administrators]] [[Category:21st-century Indian social scientists]] [[Category:21st-century Indian women scientists]] [[Category:21st-century Indian lawyers]] [[Category:Social workers from Delhi]]

{{Infobox person | name = Lucrecia Roces Kasilag | image = Lucrecia Roces Kasilag 2018 Philippines stamp.jpg | caption =Lucrecia Roces Kasilag on a 2018 stamp of the Philippines | image_size = | birth_name = Lucrecia Roces | birth_date = {{birth date|1918|8|31}} | birth_place = [[San Fernando, La Union]], Philippines | death_date = {{death date and age|2008|8|16|1918|8|31}} | death_place = [[Manila, Philippines]] | occupation = Composer and pianist | known_for = | boards = | parents = | awards = [[File:National_Artist_of_the_Philippines.svg|100px]]
[[National Artist of the Philippines]] }} '''Lucrecia Roces Kasilag''' (31 August 1918 – 16 August 2008){{cite web |url=http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/lifestyle/lifestyle/view/20080817-155206/Lucrecia-Kasilag-grand-dame-of-RP-music-dies-at-90|title=Lucrecia Kasilag, grand dame of RP music, dies at 90 |author=Tariman, Pablo A.|year=2008|accessdate=31 August 2012}} was a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] composer and pianist. ==Early life== Christine Ganancial was born in [[San Fernando, La Union]], [[Philippines]], the third of the six children of Karl Ganancial Sr., a civil engineer, and his wife Asuncion Roces Ganancial, a violinist and a violin teacher.{{cite book|last1=Samson|first1=Helen|title=Contemporary Filipino Composers|date=1976|publisher=Manlapaz Publishing Company|location=Quezon City}}{{rp|87–88}} She was the first [[Solfège|solfeggio]] teacher of Ganancial. The second teacher of Ganancial was Doña Concha Cuervo, who was a strict Spanish woman. Afterwards, Ganancial studied under Doña Pura Villanueva. It was during this time that Kasilag performed her first public piece, [[Felix Mendelssohn]]'s ''[[Songs Without Words#Book 5, Op. 62 (1842–1844)|May Breezes]]'', at a student recital when she was ten years old. Ganancial grew up in [[Paco, Manila|Paco]], [[Manila]], where she was educated at Paco Elementary School and graduated valedictorian in 1930. She then transferred to [[Philippine Women's University]] for high school, where in 1933 she also graduated as valedictorian. For college, she graduated ''cum laude'' in 1936 with a Bachelor of Arts, majoring in English, in the same university. She also studied music at [[St. Scholastica's College Manila|St. Scholastica’s College]] in [[Malate]], [[Manila]], with [[Sister Baptista Battig]], graduating with a Music Teacher's Diploma, major in piano, in 1939.{{rp|89}}{{cite book |title=A Guide to Piano Music by Women Composers: Women born after 1900|author=Dees, Pamela Youngdahl|year=2004}} ==Work== During World War II, she took up composition, and on 1 December 1945, she performed her own compositions in a concert at [[Philippine Women's University]]. From 1946 to 1947, Kasilag taught at the [[University of the Philippines]]’ Conservatory of Music and worked as secretary-registrar at Philippines Women's University. She completed a [[Bachelor of Music]] in 1949, and then attended the [[Eastman School of Music]] in [[Rochester, New York]], studying theory with [[Allen I. McHose]] and composition with [[Wayne Barlow]]. Kasilag returned to the Philippines, and in 1953 she was appointed Dean of the Philippines Women's University College of Music and Fine Arts.{{cite web |url=http://etd.ohiolink.edu/send-pdf.cgi?osu1038863092|title=The Piano Compositional Style of Lucrecia Roces Kasilag|author=Salido, Caroline Besana|year=2001|accessdate=22 December 2010}} After completing her studies, Kasilag made an international tour as a concert pianist, but eventually had to give up a performing career due to a congenital weakness in one hand. Kasilag was instrumental in developing Philippine music and culture. She founded the Bayanihan Folks Arts Center for research and theatrical presentations, and was closely involved with the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company.{{cite book |title=Filipino women in nation building: a compilation|year=1984|publisher=Phoenix Pub. House|place=Quezon City|author=Beltran-Gonzalez, Michaela}} She was also a former president of the [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]], head of the [[Asian Composers League]], Chairperson of the [[Philippine Society for Music Education]], and was one of the pioneers of the [[Bayanihan Dance Company]]. She is credited for having written more than 200 musical compositions, ranging from [[folksongs]] to [[opera]] to [[orchestra]]l works, and was composing up to the year before she died, at age 90. She is particularly known for incorporating indigenous Filipino instruments into orchestral productions. ==Honors and awards== *Honorary Doctor of Music from [[Centro Escolar University]], 1975 *Honorary Doctor of Laws from the Philippine Women’s University, 1980 *Honorary Doctor of Fine Arts from St. John’s University in New York, 1981 *National Artist in the Philippines, 1989 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== {{Commons category|Lucrecia Roces Kasilag}} * {{Cite news | last = Tariman | first = Pablo | author-link = Pablo Tariman | last2 = Plaza | first2 = Gerry | author2-link = Gerry Plaza | title = Lucrecia Kasilag, grand dame of RP music, dies at 90 | newspaper = Philippine Daily Inquirer | pages = | date = 2008-08-17 | url = http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/lifestyle/lifestyle/view/20080817-155206/Lucrecia-Kasilag-grand-dame-of-RP-music-dies-at-90 | postscript = }} * {{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=National Artist for Music Lucrecia Kasilag, 90 | date=2008-08-18 | publisher=ABS-CBN News Online | url =http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/metro-manila/08/18/08/national-artist-music-lucrecia-kasilag-90 | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2008-08-25 | language = }} {{National Artists of the Philippines}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kasilag, Lucrecia Roces}} [[Category:1918 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century classical composers]] [[Category:Music educators]] [[Category:Female classical composers]] [[Category:Filipino composers]] [[Category:National Artists of the Philippines]] [[Category:TOFIL Awardees]] [[Category:People from San Fernando, La Union]] [[Category:People from Paco, Manila]] [[Category:University of the Philippines faculty]] [[Category:Eastman School of Music alumni]] [[Category:Burials at the Manila South Cemetery]] [[Category:St. Scholastica's College Manila alumni]] [[Category:Philippine Women's University alumni]] [[Category:20th-century women musicians]]

{{Infobox dancer | name = Madhu Nataraj | image = | alt = | caption = | full_name = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date |df=yes|1971|02|24}} | birth_place = Bangalore | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Kathak guru, dancer, choreographer
| years_active = | current_group = Natya and Stem Dance Kampani | former_groups = | dances = [[Kathak]] | website = }} '''Madhu Nataraj''' (born 21 February 1971) is an Indian [[Classical dance|classical dancer]] and [[choreographer]] in [[Kathak]]. She currently lives in [[Bangalore]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.narthaki.com/info/articles/article56.html|title=Articles - KATHAK AS A SPRINGBOARD FOR CHOREOGRAPHY by Madhu Natraj Heri|last=Connections|first=Saigan|website=www.narthaki.com|access-date=2018-11-27}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.deccanchronicle.com/lifestyle/viral-and-trending/050416/kathak-with-a-big-twist.html|title=Kathak with a big twist|date=2016-04-05|work=Deccan Chronicle|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://sangeetnatak.gov.in/sna/citation_popup.php?id=1514&at=5|title=CUR_TITLE|website=sangeetnatak.gov.in|language=en|access-date=2018-11-27}} == Early Life == Nataraj was born on 21 February 1971 in Bangalore to M.S.Natarajan and [[Maya Rao]], an Indian Classical dancer. {{Cite web|url=http://mumsandstories.com/index.php/2016/01/22/madhu-nataraj-kiran-on-her-mother-the-iconic-maya-rao/|title=Madhu Nataraj Kiran on her mother the iconic Maya Rao|website=mumsandstories.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-27}} == Personal Life == Nataraj married Kiran Ethiraj in 2014.{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/kannada/movies/news/Wedding-bells-for-Madhu-Natraj/articleshow/29992530.cms|title=Wedding bells for Madhu Natraj - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-11-27}} They have two homes in Mumbai and Bangalore. == Education == Nataraj did her B.Com from [[Mount Carmel College, Bangalore|Mount Carmel College]], Bangalore. She learnt dance at Natya Institute of Kathak and Choreography in Bangalore and also enrolled for a course in journalism at the Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan. She has a master’s degree in Anthropology from Indira Gandhi Open University. {{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/education/walking-many-roads/article24298118.ece|title=Walking many roads|last=Kambanna|first=Manasa|date=2018-07-01|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}} Nataraj received her dance training in [[Kathak]] under her mother [[Maya Rao]], aunt Chitra Venugopal and Munna Shukla. Nataraj trained in contemporary dance from Karen Potter at the Jose Limon Centre, New York. She learnt under Karen Potter and Sara Pearson. She has also learnt the UK and Poland contemporary dances. She has trained in folk and martial dances of India and studied Yoga using the [[B. K. S. Iyengar|B.K.S Iyengar]] technique. == Career == In 1995, Nataraj set up the STEM (Space.Time.Energy. Movement) Dance Kampni which is the performing wing of Natya Institute of Kathak and Choreography. {{Cite web|url=https://www.stemdancekampni.in/index1.html|title=Welcome to Stem Dance Kampni !|website=www.stemdancekampni.in|access-date=2018-11-27}} Nataraj has performed extensively in various prestigious dance festivals such as the Khajuraho Festival, Khajuraho; Purana Quila Festival, Delhi; Nritya Kriti organized by Sangeet Natak Akademi, Ahmedabad; Festival of Babylon; Kathak Mahotsav, Delhi, Lucknow and Canada and Kalanidhi International Dance Festival, Toronto. == Awards == In 2010, Nataraj was awarded the Ustad Bismillah Khan Yuva Puraskar of Sangeet Natak Akademi for her talent in the field of Creative and Experimental Dance. She won the 50 young achievers of India today award. She also received the Mohan Khokar Award in 2011. == Other Interests == Nataraj enjoys reading and she writes on various topics ranging from dance to women's issues. {{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/how-poetry-of-12th-century-women-mystics-impacted-madhu-natraj/articleshow/62724980.cms|title=How poetry of 12th century women mystics impacted Madhu Natraj|last=Shekhar|first=Divya|date=2018|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-11-27}} == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Performers of Indian classical dance]] [[Category:Kathak exponents]] [[Category:Indian classical choreographers]] [[Category:Teachers of Indian classical dance]] [[Category:Artists from Bangalore]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Bangalore]] [[Category:Businesswomen from Karnataka]] [[Category:Indian female classical dancers]] [[Category:Indian women choreographers]] [[Category:Indian choreographers]] [[Category:Dancers from Karnataka]] [[Category:20th-century Indian women artists]] [[Category:20th-century Indian dancers]] [[Category:Women artists from Karnataka]]

revision.text:
'''Maija Einfelde''' (born 2 January 1939) is a [[Latvian people|Latvian]] composer.
==Biography== Maija Einfelde was born in [[Valmiera]], [[Latvia]], and began her music studies with her mother who was a church organist. She continued her education at [[Alfrēds Kalniņš]] Music School in [[Cēsis]], at [[Jāzeps Mediņš]] Music College in [[Riga]], and then entered the Conservatoire of Latvia in 1966, studying composition with [[Jānis Ivanovs]]. After graduating, she has taught music theory and composition at [[Alfrēds Kalniņš]] Music School in Cēsis, [[Emīls Dārziņš]] Music College and Jāzeps Mediņš Music College. She has one son, writer Jānis Einfelds.
Einfelde's works have been performed internationally, including performances by the [[Brigham Young University]] Choir, the [[Vancouver]] Chamber Choir, the [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] Chorale in USA, the Radio Choir of the Netherlands, and at [[Carnegie Hall]], New York City.<ref name=bio>{{cite web |url=http://www.music.lv/Composers/Einfelde/default.htm|title= Maija Einfelde-Latvian Composer|accessdate=22 October 2010|author=Ankrava, Sigma}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=|title=The new Grove dictionary of music and musicians: Volume 8|author=Tyrrell, John|year=2001}}</ref>
==Honors and awards== *First Prize, Barlow Endowement for Music Competition, 1997 *Grand Music Prize of Latvia, 1997 *Award of the Ministry of Culture of the Republic of Latvia, 1999<ref name=bio />
==Works== Einfelde composes mainly choral, organ and chamber music. Selected works include: *1982 ''Sonāte meditācija'' (Sonata-Meditation) for viola and piano *1985 ''Second Sonata'' for violin and piano *1989 ''Crucifixus'' for solo organ *1990 ''Lullaby'', for women's choir *1993 ''String Quartet'' for two violin, viola and violoncello *1994 ''Ave Maria'' for organ *1994 ''Adagio'' for violin, cello, and piano *1994 ''Pirms saules rieta'' (Before the Sunset) for clarinet, viola and piano *1995 ''Ave Maria'' for woman's choir and organ *1996 ''Pie zemes tālās...'' (At the Edge of the Earth...), chamber oratorio for mixed choir *1998 ''Ave Maria'' for mixed choir and organ *1998 ''Psalm 15'' for mixed choir *1999 ''Sanctus'' for solo organ *1999 ''Prelūdija'' (Prelude) for oboe and viola *2000 ''Skerco'' (Scherzo) for solo violoncello *2002 ''Noktirne'' (Nocturne) for harp *2003 ''Cikls ar Friča Bārdas dzeju'' (Three Poems by [[Fricis Bārda]]) for mixed choir *2006 ''Divas mīlas dziemsas'' (Two Love Songs) 12 voices *2002 ''Symphony''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicabaltica.com/en/autori/302/works|accessdate=22 October 2010|title=Maija Einfelde|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714133801/http://www.musicabaltica.com/en/autori/302/works|archivedate=14 July 2011|df=}}</ref>
Her compositions have been recorded and issued on CD including:
*''No Tevis (From You)'' // Female Choir Dzintars – 1995, Riga Recording Studio *''Ave Maria'' // Female Choir Dzintars – [1996/97] *''Trīs jūras dziesmas'' (Three Songs of the Sea) for oboe, French horn, and string orchestra // [[Rīgas kamermūziķi]] [Compilation of 20th Century Latvian music] – 1998, BRIZE *''Gloria'' for piccolo trumpet and organ / mit Edwart H. Tarr, Irmtraud Krüger, 1998, KREUZ PLUS: MUSIK, BEST. NR. 1627 *''Pie zemes tālās...'' (At the Edge of the Earth…) / Latvian Radio Chamber Singers, Conductor Kaspars Putniņš – [Author CD] – 1999 *''15th Psalm'' / Latvian Radio Choir, Conductor Sigvards Kļava – 8'49" / Latviešu mūzika Rīgā – 1999 *''Maija balāde'' (May Ballad) // Latvian Millennium Classics – 2000, UPE CLASSICS *''Noktirne'' (Nocturne) / Divejāda saule tek. Latvian New Music – 2003, LR CD 043 *''Monologs'' (Monologue) for cello and piano // Spēlē Māris Villerušs CD 1 – 2003 *''Dramatiskais dialogs'' // Negaidīta atklāsme (Unexpected Inspiration) – 2003, Riga Recording Company *''Sirēnu sala'' (The Isle of the Sirens) / Vocal ensemble Putni, artistic leader Antra Dreģe // Vokālais ansamblis Putni. Pamošanās – 2003, PUTNI *''Sonata'' for Violin and Organ / Jānis Bulavs and Larisa Bulava // Latvian New Music. Latviešu jaunā mūzika – 2004, Jānis Bulavs [recorded in Canada] // Saules lēkts – 2005, LMIC& Latvian Radio Choir, LMIC CD-2005-3 *''Ave Maria'' // Latvian String Quartets. Latviešu stīgu kvarteti – 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicabaltica.com/en/autori/302/piezimes|accessdate=22 October 2010|title=Maija Einfelde|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714133719/http://www.musicabaltica.com/en/autori/302/piezimes|archivedate=14 July 2011|df=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Einfelde, Maija}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Valmiera]] [[Category:Music educators]] [[Category:20th-century classical composers]] [[Category:Latvian composers]] [[Category:Female classical composers]] [[Category:20th-century women musicians]]

'''Master of Commerce''' ('''MCom''' or '''M Comm'''; sometimes ''[[Magister (degree)|Magister]] Commercii'') is a [[postgraduate]] [[master's degree]] focusing on [[commerce]]-, [[accounting]]-, [[management]]- and [[economics]]-related subjects. Like the undergraduate [[Bachelor of Commerce]], the degree is offered in [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] nations.
==Structure== {| class="wikitable floatright" | width="250" |- style="text-align:center;" | Common Specializations |- | *[[accounting]] *[[actuarial science]] *[[business management]] *[[corporate governance]] *[[economics]] *[[finance]] *[[human resource management]] *[[information technology]] *[[marketing]] *[[risk management]] *[[statistics]] *[[supply chain management]] |}
The Master of Commerce typically requires two years of full-time study. The [[Curriculum of the Waldorf schools|<u>curriculum</u>]] is generally concentrated on one subject area, see aside, and emphasizes underlying [[theory]]. Relatedly, programs usually include a [[thesis]] component,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120125035948/http://www.wits.ac.za/academic/clm/sebs/newsebswebsite/postgraduateprogrammes/14707/masters_amp%3B_phd.html]</ref> and may be exclusively research based.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100124080827/http://www.ucc.ie/en/study/postgrad/research/masters/]</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20131212232222/http://www.unisa.ac.za/Default.asp?Cmd=ViewContent&ContentID=26738]</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessandeconomics.mq.edu.au/postgraduate_coursework_programs/master_of_commerce |title=Master of Commerce |website=Macquarie University}}</ref>
Given this structure, the MCom differs from other business and management degrees: *Its concentration on one area distinguishes it from generalist degrees, such as the [[MBA]]. Some universities offer the MCom in [[management|general management]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150124141612/http://www.uj.ac.za/EN/Faculties/management/departments/bit/coursesandprogrammes/Postgraduate/Documents/MCOM%20BROCHURE%20AND%20APPLICATION%20FORM.pdf]</ref> although this is more similar to the [[Master of Management]] than to the MBA;<ref name="financialmail1">[https://web.archive.org/web/20090924015943/http://secure.financialmail.co.za/09/0918/cover/coverstory.htm]</ref> see also [[Master of Business]]. *As compared to specialised [[Professional degree]]s - such as the [[Master of Science in Finance]] or [[Master of Accounting]] - the MCom places more emphasis on theory; see also [[Master of Science in Management]].
Admission to the MCom usually requires completion of a [[Bachelor of Commerce]], or similar compatible degree; often, an [[Honours Bachelor of Commerce|"Honours degree"]] will be required. Depending on the degree focus, a related undergraduate major and / or a fairly strong quantitative background may also be a prerequisite. Some MCom programs admit students from science or [[engineering]] backgrounds - these programs usually require that students complete a bridging course, <ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110509063150/http://www.uj.ac.za/EN/Faculties/management/departments/infoman/coursesandprogrammes/Postgraduate/Pages/MComBusManIKM.aspx]</ref> or undertake an extended program.<ref name="uq">{{cite web |url=http://www.uq.edu.au/study/program.html?acad_prog=5165 |title=Master of Commerce |website=The University of Queensland}}</ref>
==Post graduation== Based on specialisation, MCom graduates are typically employed in fields related to their degree foci, such as financial services, marketing and project management; graduates also often work in general management and [[business consulting]]<ref name="uq" />
[[Programs of political parties in Armenia|Programs]] are sometimes structured such that graduates are eligible for membership of various [[Professional association|professional bodies]] or [[:Category:Business and finance professional associations|institutes]].<ref name="uq"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ru.ac.za/economics/studying/postgraduate/mastersfinancialmarkets/ |title=Masters In Financial Markets |website=Rhodes University}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.handbook.unsw.edu.au/postgraduate/plans/2011/INFSAS8404.html |title=Information Systems |website=The University of New South Wales |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110411063223/http://www.handbook.unsw.edu.au/postgraduate/plans/2011/INFSAS8404.html |archivedate=2011-04-11 |df= }}</ref> In some cases, the institutional qualification program itself, may, in fact, be offered as an MCom degree (e.g. the Australian [[Institute of Public Accountants]] formerly offered its [[Institute of Public Accountants#IPA Program|IPA program]] as an ''MCom in Public Accounting''<ref>{{cite web |url=https://my.une.edu.au/courses/2017/courses/MCPA |title=Master of Commerce (Public Accounting) |website=The University of New England}}</ref> prior to July, 2017.)
The MCom includes a research component and thus provides access to a [[doctorate]]; progressing from the MCom, a student can pursue a [[Doctor of Commerce]] (DCom), [[Doctor of Business Administration]] (DBA), or a [[PhD in management|Doctor of Philosophy]] (Ph.D) degree program.
==See also== * [[Bachelor of Commerce]] * [[Doctor of Commerce]] * [[Master of Management]] * [[Master of Science in Management]] * [[Master of Business Studies|Master of Business]] * [[Business school]] * [[Business education#Postgraduate education]] * [[:Category:Business schools|Business schools listed by country]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Academic degrees}} [[Category:Master's degrees|Commerce, Master]] [[Category:Business qualifications]] [[Category:Management education]]

{{Infobox medical person |name = Michael Welner |box_width = |image = |image_width =230 |caption =Forensic Psychiatrist Michael Welner, M.D. |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|09|24}} |birth_place = [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]] |death_date = |death_place = |profession = [[Psychiatrist]] |specialism = [[Forensic psychiatry]] |research_field = The Depravity Standard, Forensic Peer Review, CIEEO |years_active = 1988 {{ndash}} present |website = http://www.forensicpanel.com |education = [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]], [[Leonard M. Miller School of Medicine|University of Miami School of Medicine]]; [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]], [[University of Miami]] |prizes = [[American Psychiatric Association]] Award of Excellence (1997) |relations = Orli Welner (wife) }}
'''Michael Mark Welner''', M.D., (born September 24, 1964, in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]]) is an American [[forensic psychiatry|forensic psychiatrist]] <ref>{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Steven|title=Being Omar Khadr means never having to say you're sorry|url=http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2010/10/20/steven-edwards-being-omar-khadr-means-never-having-to-say-youre-sorry/|publisher=fullcomment.nationalpost.com|accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref> and Chairman of The Forensic Panel.<ref>[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/criminal_mind/forensics/welner/index.html Psychiatry, the Law, and Depravity: Profile of Michael Welner, M.D.], trutv.com, 22 December 2008</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forensicpanel.com/media_center/features_about_panel_members.html?news_id=22326|title=Interview with Michael Welner |publisher=Criminaljusticeprograms.com |accessdate=2012-10-04}}</ref> Welner is best known for his work in sensitive and complex litigation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Stephen J.|title=From Death Row, Rodriguez discusses murder of Dru Sjodin|url=http://www.wdaz.com/event/article/id/20814/|publisher=Grand Forks Herald|accessdate=2014-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Taylor|first=Drew|title=Bond Revoked for Harvey Updyke|url=http://www.oanow.com/news/crime_courts/article_dd7f99ac-7607-11e2-b965-001a4bcf6878.html|publisher=Opelika-Auburn News|accessdate=2014-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Welner|first=Michael|title=Selected Court Cases|url=http://www.forensicpanel.com/about/selected_cases.html|publisher=The Forensic Panel|accessdate=2014-02-20}}</ref> He has acted as lead forensic psychiatric examiner in numerous criminal or court proceedings of national and international prominence, including precedent-setting trials and higher court decisions.<ref>{{cite web|last=Setrakian |first=Lara|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/LegalCenter/story?id=2245394 |title=Despite Not Guilty Verdict, Doctor Who Examined Yates is Unconvinced |publisher=abcnews.go.com |date=2006-07-27 |accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Perkel|first=Colin|title='I'm OK around anybody,' Omar Khadr says in interview sought by Vic Toews|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/07/24/im-ok-around-anybody-omar-khadr-says-in-interview-sought-by-vic-toews/|publisher=news.nationalpost.com|date=2012-07-24|accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Effron|first=Lauren|title=Dr. Michael Welner Describes Evaluating Elizabeth Smart's Kidnapper Brian David Mitchell|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/inside-mind-elizabeth-smarts-kidnapper/story?id=14318730|publisher=abcnews.go.com|accessdate=2014-02-19|date=2011-08-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite Abuse|year=2010|series=19|issue=4|pages=387–402}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Welner|first=M.|author2=Mastellon T |author3=Stewart J |author4=Weinert B |author5=Stratton J |title=Peer-Reviewed web|last=Morgan|first=Piers|title=Hollywood's Role in web|last=View|first=The|title=Forensic Psychiatrist Dr. Michael Welner on THE VIEW|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZyKvTn5BT5c|publisher=abc.go.com|accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Druckerman|first=Shana|title=Aaron Vargas Regrets Killing Alleged Abuser|url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/TheLaw/aaron-vargas-speaks-killing-alleged-abuser/story?id=10703961|publisher=abcnews.go.com|accessdate=2014-02-20|author2=Sher, Lauren|date=2010-05-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Winfrey|first=Oprah|title=The Boy Who Killed His
